Description: Black-topped redware pottery jar: modelled on the life size scale a small lizard, perhaps a gecko. It has a black mouth. The jar was coil-built, and finger-smoothed inside. A dark red slip has been applied outside and inside rim, and vertically burnished. There is a finger-modelled figure of a lizard applied to exterior.
Curator's comments: It is hard to understand why, but the authenticity of this vessel has in the past been doubted. It has recently been tested by thermoluminescence and confirmed as ancient. Bibliography: A. Scharff in 'Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 14 (1928), pl. xxv, 14; Royal Academy of Arts, ‘5,000 years of Egyptian art : the Diploma Galleries Royal Academy of Art, London 22 June to 12 August’ (London, 1962), p. 12 [5].
Bibliographic references: Bourriau 1981 / Umm el-Ga'ab: Pottery from the Nile Valley Before the Arab Conquest (42)
Exhibition history: 2019 10 May-26 Oct, Liverpool, Victoria Gallery & Museum, Before Egypt
